exercises.topic: Intersections of straight lines and circles
Differentiating functions with two or more terms

1.question:
Evaluate x^2+{a}y-{b}
where x={x} and y={-y}
1.help: The rules of aritmetic are identical for algebra and numbers. Just substitute the values and calculate as normal.

3.question: Simplify {a}x+{b}x^2+{c}x+{d}x^2+{e}x^3
3.help: x,x^2 and x^3 are not the same. We can only collect like powers.

4.question: Expand {a}({b}x+{c})
4.help:
To expand brackets multiply every term in the bracket by the number outside.
4(2x+3)=4*2x+4*3=8x+3
Note: 4(2x+3) means 4\(\times(\)(2x+3)\()\)
We could do the same for numbers:
4(3+2)=4*3+4*2=12+8=20
but since we can calculate the bracket first it usually makes more sense to do this:
4(3+2)=4*5=20

5.question: Expand ({a}x+{b})({c}x+{d})
5.help:
To expand brackets multiply every term in the first bracket by every term in the second bracket.
(4x+2)(2x+3)
=4x(2x+3)+2(2x+3)
=4x*2x+4x*3+2*2x+2*3
=8x^2+12x+4x+6
=8x^2+16x+6
Note: 4x*2x
=4\(\times\)x*2\(\times\)x
=4*2\(\times\)x\(\times\)x
=8x^2
FOIL (first outer inner last) can be used to remember how to expand 2x2 brackets but better to understand the process which is far more general:
(3x+2y+7)(2x+z+3)
=6x^2+3xz+9x+4xy+2yz+6y+14x+7z+21
=6x^2+3xz+23x+4xy+2yz+6y+7z+21

11.question:
Solve
{a}x+{b}={c}x+{d}
11.help:
See @algebra
It is generally easiest (but not required) to collect terms such that x remains positive. 
3x+7=5x-2
7+2=5x-3x
9=2x
x=9/2
... but the alternative is fine too
3x+7=5x-2
3x-5x=-2-7
-2x=-9
x=(-9)/-2=9/2

12.help:
See @negatives
Be careful when squaring negative \(a\) and subtracting 'a multiple of negative\(b\)
\(-×-=+\)
\(- -=+\)

15.question:
Evaluate ({a^b}/{d^b})^-{c/b}
Give your answer as a fraction in its simplest form.
15.help:
See @powers
Take the calculation one step at a time.
Note (x/y)^-z=(y/x)^z=y^z/x^z
consider:
(x/y)^-1=1/(x/y)=1*(y/x)=y/x
(x/y)^3=x/y*(x/y)*(x/y)=x^3/y^3

17.question: Re-write ({a^b})^{c} in the form {a}^n
17.help: See @powers a^n a is known as the base and n is know as the exponent. To change base we must find 'a power of our new base which equals the original and then use the power rules to calculate the new exponent. E.g. to convert 25^4 to 5^n we re-write as (5^2)^4=5^8 It is sometimes necessary to change base to proceed with 'a calculation since power arithmetic requires 'a common base. E.g. 25^4*5^3=5^8*5^3=5^11

18.question: Expand ({a}x+{b})({c}x+{d})
18.help:
See @algebra
To expand brackets multiply every term in the first bracket by every term in the second bracket.
(4x+2)(2x+3)
=4x(2x+3)+2(2x+3)
=4x*2x+4x*3+2*2x+2*3
=8x^2+12x+4x+6
=8x^2+16x+6
Note: 4x*2x
=4\(\times\)x*2\(\times\)x
=4*2\(\times\)x\(\times\)x
=8x^2
FOIL (first outer inner last) can be used to remember how to expand 2x2 brackets but better to understand the process which is far more general:
(3x+2y+7)(2x+z+3)
=6x^2+3xz+9x+4xy+2yz+6y+14x+7z+21
=6x^2+3xz+23x+4xy+2yz+6y+7z+21

19.question:
{a,mixed}\(\div\){b,mixed}\(=\)
Give your answer as a mixed number in its simplest form. E.g. for 1+2/3 enter '1+2/3

21.question:
{a}+{b}=
Give your answer in its simplest form.
21.help:
We can add fractions which have a common denominator but may need to simplify our answer (see @fractions) E.g.
 1/4 + 1/4 = 2/4 = 1/2

22.question:
{a}+{b}=
Give your answer as a mixed number in its simplest form. E.g. for 1+2/3 enter '1+2/3
22.help:
Add and convert to a mixed number simplifying if needed (see @fractions). E.g.
 5/8+7/8=12/8=3/2= 1+1/2

23.question:
{a}+{b}=
Give your answer in its simplest form.
23.help:
To add find 'a common denominator (see @fractions). E.g.
 2/3 + 1/4 = 8/12 + 3/12 = 11/12

24.question:
{a}-{b}=
Give your answer in its simplest form.
24.help:
To subtract fractions first find a common denominator (see @fractions).
 5/6-1/4=10/12-3/12=7/12

25.question:
{a}*{b}=

Give your answer in its simplest form.
25.help:
Multiplication does not need a common denominator. Just multiply the numerators and multiply the denominators (see @fractions).
2/3*{3/4}=2*3/(3*4)=6/12=1/2
Better still cancel down early to keep numbers small and avoid the need to simplify
2/3*{3/4}=\(\dfrac{\color{pink}2 1}{\color{lightblue}{3} 1}\times\dfrac{\color{lightblue}{3} 1}{\color{pink}{4} 2}\)= 1/2

26.question:
{a}\(\div\){b}=

Give your answer as a mixed number in its simplest form. E.g. for 1+2/3 enter '1+2/3

Give your answer in its simplest form.
26.help:
Division is the opposite of multiplication. Dividing by \(\frac{1}{2}\) is the same as multiplying by 2 (see @fractions).
To divide fractions flip the fraction you are dividing by and multiply. 
2/3\(\div\)3/4= 2/3*(4/3)=8/9

27.question:
{a,mixed}\(+\){b,mixed}\(=\)
Give your answer as a mixed number in its simplest form. For 3+2/3 enter '3+2/3
27.help:
To add mixed numbers split the sum into two and then recombine.
1+2/3\(+\)2+3/4
=1+2+2/3+3/4
=3 + 17/12
=4+5/12
Note: you could convert to improper fractions first but this will result in extra work.

28.question:
{a,mixed}\(-\){b,mixed}\(=\)
Give your answer as a mixed number in its simplest form. E.g. for -1-2/3 enter '-1-2/3
28.help:
To subtract mixed numbers split the sum into two and then recombine.
E.g.
2+2/3\(-\)1+3/4
=2-1+2/3-3/4
=1-1/12
= 11/12

30.question:
{a,mixed}\(\div\){b,mixed}\(=\)
Give your answer as a mixed number in its simplest form. E.g. for 1+2/3 enter '1+2/3
30.help:
2+2/3\(\div\)1+3/4
Dividing mixed numbers is tricky. You must first turn the 2nd fraction into an improper fraction. You can then multiply out the parts.
=2+2/3\(\div\)7/4
=(2+2/3)(4/7)
=2*(4/7)+2/3*(4/7)
={2*4/7}+{2/3*4/7}={2*4/7+2/3*4/7}
=1+11/21
or convert both to improper
=8/3\(\div\)7/4
=8/3*(4/7)={8/3*4/7}
={8/3*4/7,mixed}

33.question: {a}*{b}+{c}*{d}=
33.help: Do the two multiplications before you do the addition (see @precedence).

37.help:
The rules for algebra are identical to the rules for numbers.
Just replace the letters with their values and calculate as normal.

38.help:
Be careful when squaring negative \(a\) and subtracting 'a multiple of negative\(b\)
\(-\times-=+\)
\(- -=+\)

40.question:
expand and simplify
-{a}x-{b}({c}-x)
40.help:
Take care when expanding brackets which contain negatives. You will often end up with \(-\times-=+\) or \( - -=+\)
Note: if you end up with 1x this is simply x

41.question: Evaluate {a}^{b}
41.help:
a^n means a multiplied by itself n times.
2^5 = 2*2*2*2*2

45.question:
Evaluate {a}^{-b}
Give your answer as 'a fraction in its simplest form

46.question: Simplify ({a}^{b})^{c}
46.help:
When raising power to powers we end up multiplying.
(2^5)^3=2^(5*3)=2^15
consider:
=2^5*2^5*2^5
=2^(5+5+5)
=2^(3*5)
=2^15
Note the brackets are important. Unlike most mathematics powers are defined to work from right to left. Without brackets 2^5^3 means \(2^{({5}^3)}\)=2^{5^3}
It is rare to encounter triple-decker powers like this.

47.question: Re-write ({a^b})^{c} in the form {a}^n
47.help: a^n a is known as the base and n is know as the exponent. To change base we must find 'a power of our new base which equals the original and then use the power rules to calculate the new exponent. E.g. to convert 25^4 to 5^n we re-write as (5^2)^4=5^8 It is sometimes necessary to change base to proceed with 'a calculation since power arithmetic requires 'a common base. E.g. 25^4*5^3=5^8*5^3=5^11

48.question: Evaluate {a^b}^{1/b}
48.help:
a^(1/n)=\(\sqrt[n]a\)

consider:
(a^(1/n))^n=a^(n/n)=a^1=a
(a^(1/n))^n=a so a^(1/n)=\(\sqrt[n]a\)

\(\sqrt[n]a\) means the  \(n\)th root of \(a\), i.e. what number multiplied by itself n times gives \(a\).The root symbol alone means the square root, so \(\sqrt{}\) means the same as \(\sqrt[2]{}\)
8^(1/3)=\(\sqrt[3]8\)=2 since 2*2*2=8 

Note: the root symbol specifically means the positive root. For even powers we need to be careful solving equations of the form a^(2n)=x since both \(\sqrt[2n]x\) and \(-\sqrt[2n]x\) are solutions. This is typically show as \(\pm\sqrt[2n]x\).
x^2=4 \(\Longrightarrow x=\pm\sqrt{4}=\pm 2\) since 2*2=4 and -2*-2=4 (see @negatives)

51.question:
{a,mixed}\(-\){b,mixed}\(=\)
Give your answer as a mixed number in its simplest form. E.g. for 1+2/3 enter '1+2/3, for -1-2/3 enter '-1-2/3
51.help:
See @fractions
To subtract mixed numbers split the sum into two and then recombine.
E.g.
2+2/3\(-\)1+3/4
=2-1+2/3-3/4
=1-1/12
= 11/12

53.question: Evaluate {a^b}^-{c/b}
53.help:
When faced with a power like \(-\frac{3}{4}\) just do it one step at a time (it doesn't matter which order you do it in). If raising a fraction to a negative power it is generally easiest to invert the fraction to deal with the negative first.
(1/81)^-(3/4)=81^(3/4)
It is generally better to take the root before raising to the power to keep numbers small.
81^-(3/4)=3^-3=1/3^3=1/27

54.question:
Evaluate ({a^b}/{d^b})^-{c/b}
Give your answer as a fraction in its simplest form.
54.help:
Take the calculation one step at a time.
Note (x/y)^-z=(y/x)^z=y^z/x^z
consider:
(x/y)^-1=1/(x/y)=1*(y/x)=y/x
(x/y)^3=x/y*(x/y)*(x/y)=x^3/y^3

59.question: -{a}*{b}\(+\){-c}*{d}=
59.help:
The multiplications give two negatives. Adding 'a negative is the same as subtracting \(+ -=-\) (see @negatives, @precedence).
Note: although it is mathematically clear we would not normally write \(+ -\) simplifying instead to \(-\)

60.question: -{a}*{b}-{c}*-{d}=
60.help:
Lots of negatives to deal with. You should end up subtracting the first multiplication from the second. 
E.g. -2*3-4*-5  = -6+20 = 20-6 = 14  (see @negatives, @precedence, @commutative).

61.question: -{a}*-{b}\(-\)-{c}*-{d}=
61.help:
You should end up subtracting the second multiplication from the first. E.g. 
-2*-3\(-\)-4*-5
=6-20
=-14
Tip: if subtracting large from small do the other way and then change the sign e.g. 
6-20=-(20-6)=-14
Note: although it is mathematically clear we would not normally write \(- -\) simplifying instead to \(+\).

62.question:
expand and simplify
{a}x-{b}(x-{c})
62.help:
See @algebra. Be careful with negatives when expanding brackets. You often end up with \(-\times-=+\) or \(- -=+\)
Note: if you end up with 1x this is simply x

63.question:
x={a}y+{b}z+{c}
Make y the subject of the formula
63.help:
Solving an equation and changing the subject of a formula are identical processes. Do exactly the same to both sides until you isolate the term you are interested in.
x=3y+2z-5
x-2z+5=3y
y=(x-2z+5)/3
Be careful with @precedence when entering your answer for (x-2z+5)/3 you must enter '(x-2z+5)/3 not 'x-2z+5/3 which means x-2z+5/3

64.question:
A random sample of 35 homeowners was taken from each of the villages Greenslax and Penville and their ages were recorded.  The results are summarised in the back-to-back stem and leaf diagram below.
/images/S1_2014_June/1a.png
Some of the quartiles for these two distributions are given in the table below.
[ , Greenslax, Penville
 Lower quartile Q_1,a,31
 Median Q_2,64,39
 Upper Quartile Q_3,b,55] 
Find the value of a and the value of b.
64.help: Find n/4 and 3n/4 and round up (or take mid point if whole number).
64.variables: xyz=Q_1 Q_2 Q_3 a b n

65.question:
A random sample of 35 homeowners was taken from each of the villages Greenslax and Penville and their ages were recorded.  The results are summarised in the back-to-back stem and leaf diagram below.
/images/S1_2014_June/1a.png
Quartiles for these two distributions are given in the table below.
[ , Greenslax, Penville
Lower quartile Q_1, 44,31
Median Q_2,64,39
Upper Quartile Q_3,76,55] 
An outlier is a value that falls either more than 1.5*(Q_3-Q_1) above Q_3 or more than 1.5*(Q_3-Q_1) below Q_1

Draw a box plot to represent the data from Penville.  Show clearly any outliers. Complete this question on paper and then use <r>Show</r> to self-mark.

66.question:
A random sample of 35 homeowners was taken from each of the villages Greenslax and Penville and their ages were recorded.  The results are summarised in the back-to-back stem and leaf diagram below.
/images/S1_2014_June/1a.png
Quartiles for these two distributions are given in the table below.
[ , Greenslax, Penville
Lower quartile Q_1, 44,31
Median Q_2,64,39
Upper Quartile Q_3,76,55] 
State the skewness of each distribution.  Justify your answers.
keyboard: enter +ve,-ve or sym for Greenslax,Penville e.g.
-ve,-ve
Use <r>Show</r> to check your reasons.
66.working:
Greenslax: Q_2-Q_1=20 Q_3-Q_2=12
Q_2-Q_1>Q_3-Q_2⇒ -ve skew
Penville: Q_2-Q_1=8 Q_3-Q_2=16
Q_3-Q_2>Q_2-Q_1⇒ +ve skew

67.question:
The mark, x, scored by each student who sat a statistics examination is coded using
y=1.4x-20
The coded marks have mean 60.8 and standard deviation 6.60
Find the mean and the standard deviation of x.
67.working:
60.8=1.4μ-20
μ=(60.8+20)/1.4=57.714…≈57.7
6.60=1.4σ
σ=6.60/1.4=4.714…≈4.71
note: σ measures the spread (dispersion) of data so is not impacted by subtracting 20 from each score.

68.question:
The table shows data on the number of visitors to the UK in a month, v (1000s), and the amount of money they spent, m (£ millions), for each of 8 months.
[ Number of visitors v (1000s),2450,2480,2540,2420,2350,2290,2400,2460
 Amount of money spent m (£ millions),1370,1350,1400,1330,1270,1210,1330,1350] 
You may use
S_vv=42587.5 S_vm=31512.5 S_mm=25187.5 Σv=19390 Σm=10610
Find the product moment correlation coefficient between m and v.
68.variables: xyz=r S_xy S_xx S_yy S_vv S_vm S_mm v m

69.question:
Give 'a reason to support fitting 'a regression model of the form m=a+bv to these data.
Use <r>Show</r> to self-mark once you have your answer.
69.working: The data shows strong correlation ( r close to 1) so valid to fit 'a linear regression model.

70.question: Find the value of b correct to 3 decimal places.

71.question: Find the equation of the regression line of m on v. Round terms to 3 significant figures.
71.help: \(y=a+bx\) where \(a=\bar y-b\bar x\) in formula booklet

72.question:
Interpret your value of b.
Use <r>Show</r> to self-mark once you have your answer.
72.help: Describe what b is in terms of money and visitors.
72.working: b is millions spent per 1000 visitors. So on average each additional 1000 visitors generates an extra £0.74 million.

73.question: Use your answer to 3d to estimate the amount of money spent when the number of visitors to the UK in a month is '2,500,000

74.question: Comment on the reliability of your estimate in 3f.  Give a reason for your answer.

75.question:
In a factory, three machines, J,K and L, are used to make biscuits.
 Machine J makes 25% of the biscuits.
 Machine K makes 45% of the biscuits.
 The rest of the biscuits are made by machine L.
 It is known that 2% of the biscuits made by machine J are broken, 3% of the biscuits made by machine K are broken and 5% of the biscuits made by machine L are broken.

Draw a tree diagram to illustrate all the possible outcomes and associated probabilities.
Complete this question on paper and then use <r>Show</r> to self-mark.
75.help: J,K&L are mutually exclusive (a biscuit is made by one and only one machine).

76.question:
A biscuit is selected at random.
Calculate the probability that the biscuit is made by machine J and is not broken.

77.question:
A biscuit is selected at random.
Calculate the probability that the biscuit is broken.

78.question: Given that the biscuit is broken, find the probability that it was not made by machine K.

79.question:
The discrete random variable X has the probability function
\(P(X=x)=\left\{\begin{aligned}&kx&&x=2,4,6 \\&k(x-2)\quad&&x=8\\&0&&\text{otherwise}\end{aligned}\right.\)
Find the exact value of k.

80.question: Find the exact value of F(5)

81.question: Find the exact value of E(X)

83.question: Calculate \(\text{Var}(3-4X)\) giving your answer to 3 significant figures.

84.question:
The times, in seconds, spent in a queue at a supermarket by 85 randomly selected customers, are summarised in the table below.
[ Time (seconds), Number of customers f
0-30,2
30-60,10
60-70,17
70-80,25
80-100,25
100-150,6] 
A histogram was drawn to represent these data. The 30-60 group was represented by a bar of width 1.5 cm and height 1 cm.
Find the width and height of the 70-80 group.
84.help: w∝ class width, h∝ frequency density

85.question: Use linear interpolation to estimate the median of this distribution.
85.help: How far is the median into which class?
85.working:
median =85/2=42.5 th time (if treated as continuous).
In 70-80 class, 2+10+17=29 values prior to this class
so 42.5=(42.5-39)=13.5 th value within class
70+(13.5/25)*10=75.4

median =(85+1)/2=43 rd time (if treated as discrete).
43=14 th value within class
70+(14/25)*10=75.6

86.question:
Given that x denotes the midpoint of each group in the table and Σfx=6460 Σfx^2=529400
Calculate an estimate for the mean and the standard deviation for the above data.
86.help: σ^2= mean of squares  \(-\) square of mean.
86.working:
μ=Σfx/(Σf)=6460/85={6460/85.0}
σ=√(Σfx^2/(Σf)-μ)
=√(529400/85-76^2)=21.26…≈21.3

σ=21.4 also allowed if clearly using s rather than σ

87.question:
One measure of skewness is given by coefficient of skewness =\(\dfrac{3(\text{mean}-\text{median})}{\text{standard deviation}}\)
Evaluate this coefficient and comment on the skewness of these data.
Use <r>Show</r> to check your interpretation of skewness.
87.working:
coeff =3(76-75.4)/21.3=0.84…≈0.08
Almost symmetrical and/or there is (very slight) positive skew.
coeff ≈0.06 if using median 75.6

88.question:
The heights of adult females are normally distributed with mean 160 cm and standard deviation 8 cm.
Find the probability that a randomly selected adult female has a height greater than 170 cm.
88.help: Calculate z value and use tables.

89.question:
Any adult female whose height is greater than 170 cm is defined as tall. An adult female is chosen at random.
Given that she is tall find the probability that she has a height greater than 180 cm.

90.question:
Half of tall adult females have a height greater than h cm.
Find the value of h.
90.help: Calculate z value from conditional probability and reverse look-up.

91.question:
For the events A and B,
\(P(A'∩B)\)=0.22  and  \(P(A'∩B')\)=0.18
Find \(P(A)\).

93.question:
Given that \(P(A|B)=0.6\)
Find \(P(A∩B)\)
93.working:
\(P(A|B)=\dfrac{P(A∩B)}{P(B)}\)
\(P(B)=P(A∩B)+P(A'∩B)\)
Let x=\(P(A∩B)\) then
0.6=x/(x+0.22)
0.4x=0.132
x=0.33
P(A∩B)=0.33
Note: many other valid approaches.

94.question:
Determine whether or not A and B are independent.
keyboard: Enter Y or N.
Use <r>Show</r> to check your reasons.
94.working:
Yes - independent as \(P(A|B)=P(A)=0.6\)
or
\(P(B)=P(A∩B)+P(A'∩B)\)=0.33+0.22=0.55
\(P(A)×P(B)\)=0.55*0.6=0.33=\(P(A∩B)\)
Yes - independent as \(P(A)×P(B)=P(A∩B)\)

95.question: Solve {a}x+{b}={d}
95.help:
An equation will remain true provided we do exactly the same to both sides.
1=1
1+5=1+5 \(\Rightarrow\) 6=6
6/2=6/2 \(\Rightarrow\) 3=3
We use this fact to solve equations
5x+7=3
5x+7-7=3-7
5x=3-7=-4
5x/5=(-4)/5
x=-4/5
With practice you will find you don't need all these steps but always remember that you are simply doing the same to both sides. Understanding this will help when you come to solve far more complex equations.

96.question: Solve {a}x+{b}={c}x+{d}
96.help:
Collect x terms on the left and number terms on the right.
7x-2=3x-5
7x-3x=-5+2
4x=-3
x=-3/4
Remember that with each step you are just doing exactly the same thing to each side of the equation (e.g. subtracting 3x adding 2 or diving by \(4\)).

98.question: Solve {a}x+{b}={c}x+{d}
98.help:
It is generally easiest (but not required) to collect terms such that x remains positive.
3x+7=5x-2
7+2=5x-3x
9=2x
x=9/2
… but the alternative is fine too
3x+7=5x-2
3x-5x=-2-7
-2x=-9
x=(-9)/-2=9/2

99.question:
Expand and simplify
(x+{a})(x+{b})
99.help: Multiply everything in the first bracket by everything in the second, and then collect the x terms. See @algebra Note: the ≡ symbol is a special form of =. It is used to show when two expressions are equivalent to each other (known as an identity). Identities become very important in more advanced mathematics, particularly in proofs. It is common to use = instead of ≡ but great to understand the difference.

109.question: Simplify {a}x-{c}y+{e}z+{d}y-{b}x-{f}z
109.help:
We must collect like terms as we can only add or subtract things if they are the same type of thing. Note: 1x is just x and 0x is 0 so is typically not shown.
2x-5y+3z+5y-3x+2z
=(2-3)x+(-5+5)y+(3+2)z
=-x+5z
By convention we tend to to arrange algebraic symbols in alphabetic order but this is not required. 5z-x would be equally acceptable as an answer and is arguably more elegant.

110.question:
Expand and simplify
({a}x+{b})({a}x-{b})

111.question:
Factorise
x^2+{b+a}x+{a*b}
111.help:
{xyz=b,c,x}
Factorisation is the opposite of expansion. For x^2+bx+c find factors of c which add to give b (see @quadratics)

112.question:
Factorise
x^2+{b+a}x+{a*b}
112.help:
{xyz=b,c,x}
Factorisation is the opposite of expansion. For x^2+bx+c find factors of c which add to give b (see @quadratics)

113.question:
Factorise
x^2+{b+a}x+{a*b}
113.help:
{xyz=b,c,x}
Factorisation is the opposite of expansion. For x^2+bx+c find factors of c which add to give b (see @quadratics)

115.question:
Factorise
{a*c}x^2+{a*d+b*c}x+{b*d}
115.help:
{xyz=a,b,c,x}
Factorisation is the opposite of expansion. For ax^2+bx+c find factors of ac which add to give b, then re-write to reveal the full factorisation. (see @quadratics)

120.question:
Simplify
 (x+{c})/(x+{a})-({c+b-a-d}x+{c*b-a*d})/(x^2+{b+a}x+{a*b})
120.help: Factorise the quadratic, put over a common denominator and then simplify (factorise the quadratic numerator and cancel down).

123.question: Evaluate {a}^0
123.help:
a^0=1 for all a
2^0=1 3^0=1 9^0=1 (-5)^0=1
Any number except 0 to the power of zero is 1. To see this consider the following:
7^0=7^(1-1)=7/7=1
(-9)^0=(-9)^(1-1)=(-9)/-9=1
Note: 0^0 is not defined. Try it on your calculator and you will get an error (it is similar to division 'by zero which is also not allowed).

126.question:
x={a}z/({b}(y+{d}))+{c}
Make y the subject of the formula
126.help:
See @algebra
For a more complex re-arrangement take it one step at a time, with each step moving you closer to isolating the term you are interested in. There are many routes to a correct answer and many mathematically equivalent correct answers. The best route is the one you find clearest and easiest.
If unsure use "show" to see a worked answer and take the time to understand how each step is just doing the same to each side of the equation. Once you understand "try-again".

132.question: Simplify and rationalise the denominator of  √{a*c}/√{b*c}

137.question: Complete the square. Re-write x^2+{2b}x+{c} in the form (x+b)^2+c where b,c are integers to 'be found.

151.question:
{a,mixed}\(\times\){b,mixed}\(=\)
Give your answer as a mixed number in its simplest form.  E.g. for 1+2/3 enter '1+2/3

156.question:
Solve
{a*c}x^2+{a*d+b*c}x+{b*d}=0
156.help:
{xyz=a,b,c,x}
Factorisation is the opposite of expansion. For ax^2+bx+c find factors of ac which add to give b, then re-write to reveal the full factorisation (see @quadratics).

157.question:
Find the minimum point of y=x^2-{2b}x+{c}
Give your answer as coordinates e.g. (3,5)
157.help: Complete the square to find the minimum point.

158.question:
{a,mixed}\(\times\){b,mixed}\(=\)
Give your answer as a mixed number in its simplest form. For 1+2/3 enter '1+2/3

160.question:
expand and simplify
-{a}x-{b}({c}-x)
160.help:
See @negatives and @algebra
Take care when expanding brackets which contain negatives. You will often end up with \(-\times-=+\) or \( - -=+\)
Note: if you end up with 1x this is simply x

161.question:
x={a}z/({b}(y+{d}))+{c}
Make y the subject of the formula
161.help:
For a more complex re-arrangement take it one step at a time, with each step moving you closer to isolating the term you are interested in. There are many routes to a correct answer and many mathematically equivalent correct answers. The best route is the one you find clearest and easiest.
If unsure use "show" to see a worked answer and try to understand how each step is just doing the same to each side of the equation. Then "try-again".

163.question:
Solve
x^2+{b+a}x+{a*b}=0
Give your answers comma separated. E.g. for x=5 or x=-2 enter 5,-2
163.help:
{xyz=b,c,x}
Note: solutions are the opposite sign to the factors. (see @quadratics)

168.question:
Solve {a}x^2+{b}x+{c}=0
Give your solutions separated 'by 'a comma (if required in surd form or to at least 2 decimal places). You may use the quadratic formula if required.
168.help: Factorise, complete the square or formula as required.

170.question: {a}*{b}+{c}*{d}=
170.help: Do the two multiplications before you do the addition (see @precedence).

172.question: {-a}-{b}
172.help: Starting -ve and getting even more -ve. Do not confuse with {a}\(-\)-{b}={a}+{b}={a--b}. See @negatives

173.question: {-a}-{b}*{-c}

174.question: -{a}^2+(-{b})^2\(-\){-c}
174.help: Be careful with precedence. Powers are evaluated before subtraction so -{a}^2≠{-a}^2 see @precedence and @negatives

176.question:
Solve x^2-{2b}x+{c}=0
Give your answer in surd form e.g. 2±√7
176.help: Complete the square to find roots.

177.question:
Evaluate x^2+{a}y-{b}
where x={x} and y={-y}
177.help: The rules of aritmetic are identical for algebra and numbers. Just substitute the values and calculate as normal.

196.help:
The rules for algebra are identical to the rules for numbers.
Just replace the letters with their values and calculate as normal.

commutative.title: Commutative
commutative.text:
An operator is known as commutative if switching the order of its operands gives the same result. 

Addition and multiplication are commutative:
4+5=5+4
6*7=7*6
Subtraction, division and powers are not commutative:
5-7\(\ne\)7-5
\(4\div9\ne9\div4\)
3^2\(\ne\)2^3

Treating division as fractions and "attaching" subtraction to make negatives can help make things more commutative.
-6+20=20-6
3/4*(5/6)=5/6*(3/4) =3*5/(4*6)=3/6*(5/4) (see @fractions)

fractions.title: Fractions
fractions.text: As your mathematics becomes stronger you will use fractions more and more, particularly in algebra. Make sure you understand how to add, subtract, multiply, divide and simplify. Equivalent fractions are formed by multiplying or dividing both numerator (top) and denominator (bottom) by the same amount. 6/8=3/4=9/12=600/800 You simplify a fraction by finding the smallest values (so 'numerator and 'denominator have no common factors). 600/800=3/4 You may also convert improper (top heavy) fractions into 'mixed numbers by dividing the 'denominator into the 'numerator and finding the remainder. 23/3= 7+2/3 To add or subtract fractions you must first have a common denominator. We can only add or subtract things when they are the same type of thing. 3/4+5/6=9/12+10/12=19/12= 1+7/12 2/5-1/4=8/20-5/20=3/20 Multiplication does not need a common denominator. Just multiply the 'numerators and multiply the denominators. 2/3*(3/4)=2*3/(3*4)=6/12=1/2 Better still cancel down early to keep numbers small and avoid the need to simplify. 2/3*(3/4)=\(\dfrac{\color{pink}2 1}{\color{lightblue}{3} 1}\times\dfrac{\color{lightblue}{3} 1}{\color{pink}{4} 2}\)= 1/2 of means the same as multiplying. 2/3 of 3/4=2/3*(3/4)=1/2 Division is the opposite of multiplication. Dividing by \(\frac{1}{2}\) is the same as multiplying by 2. To divide fractions flip the fraction you are dividing by and multiply. 2/3\(\div\)3/4=2/3*(4/3)=8/9 You may also think of this process in terms of simplification. 2/3÷(3/4)= (2/3)/(3/4)=(2/3*4*3)/(3/4*4*3)=8/9 Multiplying through by denominators can be a useful technique for removing double-decker fractions when they arise in more complex algebra. We tend not to use the division symbol in more advanced mathematics.

keyboard.title: Keyboard
keyboard.text:
Click <button class='btn btn-xs kbd'>​</button> to enter your answer. Use <button class='btn btn-xs btn-success'>✓</button> to mark.

A question mark will be shown where your answer can't be understood (sometimes followed by an indication of what is wrong).

The display follows the rules of @precedence. Use ^ for powers, / for division and * for multiplication.  Check that what is displayed is mathematically equivalent to what you mean and add or remove brackets as needed.
E.g. enter '3x^5/(7y^3) for 3x^5/(7y^3)

Functions (sin,cos,tan,ln etc.) are treated as having precedence between addition and multiplication, add brackets if that's not what you want. Trigonometric powers and inverse functions can be entered with ^ (e.g. sin^2 for \(\sin^2\) and sin^-1 for \(\sin^{-1}\)).

Brackets will automatically be shown where needed to avoid ambiguity and removed where they are not needed. Pay attention to what is shown to develop your understanding of @precendece (a key skill for algebraic re-arrangement).

negatives.title: Negatives
negatives.text:
Make sure you understand the rules:
\(++=+\)
\(+-=-\)
\(-+=-\)
\(- -=+\)
The last one is where most mistakes are made, particularly when squaring numbers.
(-7)^2=-7*-7=49
Also remember that if you subtract a negative number you end up adding.
5\(-\)-6=5+6=11
Two negatives don't always make a positive.
-5-6=-11
-6\(-\)-5=-6+5=-1
Be careful. More errors are made with negatives than with any other part of mathematics.

rating.title: Rating
rating.text:
After each question rate your understanding to move on to the next question.
<g>:)</g> means you understand (little practice required).
<o>:|</o> means you are unsure (more practice required).
<r>:(</r> means you do not understand. More help needed.
You may also leave a comment to refer back to later.

A detailed colour-coded record is kept of everything you do. 
Question are shown as <g>green</g> when you get them correct and rate <g>:)</g>, <r>red</r> when you get them wrong or rate <r>:(</r> or <o>amber</o> otherwise. 
Papers are marked <g>green</g> when all questions are green, <r>red</r> when any questions are red, or <o>amber</o> otherwise.

You can click on any of the paper or question links to find more detail and try again.
You may also use "Tutor" to allow parents, teachers or tutors to see your results.

Over time try to turn everything on your "Home" page <g>green</g>.

precedence.title: Precedence
precedence.text:
The more powerful the operator the sooner it is evaluated. You may know as BIDMAS, BODMAS or BEDMAS.
  • Brackets are evaluated first.
  • Powers are evaluated next (B?DMAS).
  • Division or Multiplication are evaluated next.
  • Addition or Subtraction are evaluated last.
Note: Division has the same precedence as multiplication. Addition has the same precedence as subtraction. Most calculators and computers follow the rules automatically. These rules are really important. Without precendence algebraic re-arrangement would be order-dependent, so very complex.

distributive.title: Distributive
distributive.text: An operator is known as distributive if we can expand brackets. Multiplication distributes over addition and is the most common use of the distributive property. 4(5+3)=4*5+4*3=20+12=32 Normally we would simply calculate the bracket first. So 4(5+3)=4*8=32 but if dealing with algebra we can only expand using the distributive property since we don't know values of x,y etc. 4(2x+5y)=8x+20y Powers are distributive over multiplication but not over addition. (3*5)^2=3*5*3*5=3^2*5^2 (see @commutative) (3+5)^2\(\ne\)3^2+5^2 Division is right but not left distributive over addition. (3+5)÷4=3÷4+5÷4 4÷(3+5)\(\ne\)4÷3+4÷5 it is however best to avoid division and express as fractions instead (see @fractions). (3+5)/4 or 4/(3+5)

factors.title: Factors
factors.text: Factorisation is a key skill in mathematics. One number is a factor of another if it divides into it with no remainder. 3 is a factor of 6, 4 is a factor of 20. Factors always come in pairs. 20=1*20 20=2*10 20=4*5 So 20 has factors 1,2,4,5,10 & 20 The same is true in algebra except we are also dealing with symbols in addition to numbers. x and 3 are factors of 3x. x,y,xy,x^2 and x^2y are all factors of x^3y. Prime Factorisation A particularly powerful technique when looking for factors is prime factorisation. Primes are numbers which have exactly two factors (one and themselves), so no other numbers divide into them exactly. Every number can be decomposed into the product of its prime factors. It can be helpful to think of this as the fingerprint or DNA of a number, since it is unique to every different number. We tend to use power notation to shorten the expression and arrange prime factors in size order. 8=2*2*2=2^3 45=3*3*5=3^2*5 Note: 1 is not defined as a prime since it has only one factor (itself). To find prime factors either systematically check for division by increasing primes (2,3,5,7,11...), or decompose into larger factor you can immediately spot and then break these down. 132=2*66=2*2*33=2*2*3*11=2^2*3*11 or 132=11*12=11*4*3=11*2*2*3=2^2*3*11 Once you have prime factors it is relatively easy to find all other factors by considering the different combinations. 132=\(2×(2×3×11)\)=2*66 132=\(3×(2×2×11)\)=3*44 132=\((2×2)×(3×11)\)=4*33 132=\((2×3)×(2×11)\)=6*22 132=\(11×(2×2×3)\)=11*12 Spotting factors is particularly important for solving @quadratics and simplifying @fractions Highest Common Factor When simplifying or factorising we often want to find the largest factor which divides into two different terms. 4 is the HCF of 12 and 40 3x is the HCF of 9x^2 and 12x Lowest Common Multiple Sometimes we need to find the smallest number which has two different factors, 36 is the LCM of 12 and 9 It is less common to want to find the LCM of algebraic terms however but

algebra.title: Algebra
algebra.text: Algebra replaces numbers with letters to "generalise" what the mathematics means. The rules are identical for numbers and algebra. 1+2 is a single sum, which has only one answer. x+y is every possible sum! This is amazingly powerful and gives mathematics much of its beauty. Algebra is commonly know as the language of mathematics. The main skills required for manipulating algebra are described below. Note: we try to avoid using the \(\times\) symbol with algebra. Lack of a symbol means \(\times\), so 3x means 3\(\times\)x. Substitution Substitution turns general into specific. Find x^2+5y where x=4 and y=-3 x^2+5y=4^2+5*-3=16-15=1 Collecting like terms We simplify by adding up all the terms which are the same. x+2y+3x-5y-7z+5x^2+4z-3x^2+4y =(5-3)x^2+(1+3)x+(2-5+4)y+(4-7)z =2x^2+4x+y-3z Note: 1y=y, x and x^2 are related but different terms so are collected individually. Expanding Since we don't know the values x,y etc. we can't work out the value of what is in a bracket, we can however expand brackets (see @distributive). 3(2x-5y)=3*2x+3*-5y=6x-15y When expanding multiple brackets we take each in turn and then collect like terms. (3x-2y)(x+4y)=3x(x+4y)-2y(x+4y) =3x^2+12xy-2xy-8y^2 =3x^2+10xy-8y^2 Note: xy=yx (see @commutative) You may have been taught to expand 2x2 brackets using FOIL (first outer inner last). Expanding brackets is a far more general skill than just 2x2 brackets. Factorising Factorising is the opposite of expanding. We factorise by breaking out the highest common factor of an expression. 9x^2+24x=3x(3x+8) This is an important skill. See @factors and @quadratics for more detail. Solving Solving equations is perhaps the most powerful application of algebra. The golden rule is that an equation will remain true provided you do exactly the same thing to both sides. 1=1 1+5=1+5 (1+5)*2=(1+5)*2 We use this fact to solve equations: 3x+7=5x-2 7=2x-2 (subtract 3x from each side) 9=2x (add 2 to each side) x=9/2=4.5 (divide both sides by 2) As you get more proficient with algebra you will find this becomes very natural and more visual. Additive items change sign as they go across the equals and multiplicative items go up-and-down stairs. Do however always be careful with @negatives and @precedence as this is where most errors are made. (3x+2)÷3=x+2/3 not x+2 Note: the only thing you are not allowed to do is divide by zero. Some care is also needed when taking roots to avoid losing negative solutions. Changing the subject Changing the subject of a formula is a useful skill (particularly for Physics) employing exactly the same skills as solving equations. y=3x+7 \(\Rightarrow\) x=(y-7)/3 (see solving above) These formulae are mathematically identical but the first enables us to find y if we know x, and the 2nd lets us find x if we know y. For more complex re-arrangements take it one step at a time, isolating terms which involve the subject on one side of the equation and terms which don't on the other. You may need to expand and factorise to achieve this. 4(x+3)=y(1-x) 4x+12=y-xy 4x+xy=y-12 x(4+y)=y-12 x=(y-12)/(4+y)

instructions__home.title: instructions__home
instructions__home.text:
Use the Topic list to select the area of maths you would like to work on. The site has a mixture of past paper and automated tests.

Select B1 to see a list of automated tests. More instructions are provided when you select one.

Links to download past papers, mark schemes and reports are provided. Complete and mark past papers offline and then upload your results. If you get questions wrong invest the effort to understand why and retry those questions a week or two later. Over time aim to turn every paper <g>green</g>.

The site keeps detailed records of everything you do and helps you prioritise where to invest effort. Items you flag as <r>:(</r> or <o>:|</o> will naturally float to the top of your lists (as will questions you score less marks on).

Most items drill down if you click on them and/or have hover based information.

When navigating to specific tests the first click will give you question by question analysis. The second will provide a correction sheet where you can enter updated marks. You can also get to the correction sheet direct from the topic list.

FreeMaths aims to make your practice as efficient and rewarding as possible.<g>Enjoy :)</g>.

instructions__students.title: instructions__students
instructions__students.text:
Information is broken into three sections: summary (students), tests and questions.

If you select a particular student, test or area all the figures will automatically update in all sections "drilling down" into the detail.

All sections are designed to float the most important items to the top, based on how many students flag difficulties and/or drop marks. Many items are hyper-linked and/or have hover-text providing more detail.

FreeMaths aims to make keeping track of student progress easy and efficient, whilst giving students the tools to work as independently as possible.

<o>Note:</o> the site is designed to work from a PC, tablet or phone, however to get the full power of the students page it is best used on a PC or Mac.  <g>Enjoy :)</g>

instructions.title: instructions
instructions.text:
Click <button class='btn btn-xs kbd'>​</button> to enter your answer. Use <button class='btn btn-xs btn-success'>✓</button> to mark.

<o>Hint</o> gives guidance if you are unsure how to solve a question. If you are still unsure use <r>Show</r> to see a worked answer.

After each question rate your understanding to move on to the next question.
<g>:)</g> means you understand (little practice required).
<o>:|</o> means you are unsure (more practice required).
<r>:(</r> means you do not understand. More help needed.
You may also leave a comment to refer back to later and/or advise tutors.

A detailed colour-coded record is kept of everything you do to help guide your studies. See your home page for more details.

<button class='btn btn-xs btn-default green'>?</button> provides more specific keyboard help.  <button class='btn btn-xs btn-default red'>?</button> provides more help if you get an answer wrong. <button class="btn btn-default btn-sm red kbd">✕</button> closes the keyboard.

quadratics.title: Quadratics
quadratics.text: {xyz=a,b,c,x,y,z} Quadratics are equations of the form y=ax^2+bx+c e.g. y=2x^2+3x+5 When plotted, all quadratics give the same symmetrical shape. They are all transformations of the equation y=x^2. Depending on the values of a,b & c the graphs have slightly different properties. If a is positive the graph will be U shaped (happy) if a is negative the graph will be \(\cap\) shaped (unhappy). Solving Quadratics Typically we are interested in finding the roots of 'a quadratic, also known as solving. The roots of an equation are the values for which y = 0, so for 'a quadratic ax^2+bx+c=0 Any quadratic will have 0,1 or 2 real roots depending on the values of a,b & c. Specifically it will have: 0 real roots if b^2<4ac 1 (repeated) root if b^2=4ac 2 distinct roots if b^2>4ac For this reason b^2-4ac is known as the discriminant of 'a quadratic. In terms of their graphs, 'a quadratic with no roots stays below (\(\cap\)) or above (U) but does not cross the x axis, A quadratic with one root bounces off the x axis at the root. A quadratic with two roots crosses the x-axis at the two roots, with the middle of the curve exactly half way between them. There are three related algebraic techniques for solving quadratics, described below. Factorisation To factorise 'a quadratic we split it into two brackets. x^2+5x+6≡(x+3)(x+2) To do this we must find two factors of c which add to give b. So 2*3=6 and 2+3=5 in this case. Negatives make this slightly more complicated but the same rule applies. x^2-x-6=(x-3)(x+2) since 2*-3=-6 and -3+2=-1 a larger than 1 makes this considerably more complicated as we must then find factors of ac with add to give b 2x^2+7x+6 ac=2*6=12 3*4=12 3+4=7=b we then re-write and factorise 2x^2+4x+3x+6 =2x(x+2)+3(x+2) =(2x+3)(x+2) In effect this is the reverse of what you would do in expanding the brackets, but it is tricky and takes some practice. Once factorised solving is easy. (x+3)(x+2)=0⇒(x+3)=0 or (x+2)=0 'since if the product of two numbers is zero one or the other must 'be zero. thus x=-3 or x=-2 Note: the solutions are the opposite sign to the factorisation. A common error is to forget to change the sign. Completing the square Factorisation will only work where the roots are simple. Completing the square can 'be used on any quadratic (although the quadratic formula described below is generally faster when a≠1 or if b is not even). x^2+6x+4=0 re-write x^2+bx as (x+b/2)^2-(b/2)^2 (x+3)^2-9+4=0 (x+3)^2=5 x+3=±√5 x=-3±√5 so x=-3-√5 or x=-3+√5 Note: completing the square also automatically tells us the min(U) or max(\(\cap\)) value of the function 'since this will 'be when (x+b/2)^2=0, so will 'be at (-3,-5) in the above case. Quadratic Formula The quadratic formula comes directly from completing the square (see @quadratic_formula_proof) The solutions to ax^2+bx+c=0 are given 'by x=(-b±√(b^2-4ac))/(2a) Substitute the values for a,b, & c and the formula will give the solutions. 3x^2-7x+1=0 a=3, b=-7, c=1 x=(7±√(7^2-4*3*1))/(2*3) x=(7+√37)/6 or x=(7-√37)/6 Note: deal with negatives early. \(- -7\)=7 & (-7)^2=7^2. Be careful what you type into 'a calculator as -7^2≠(-7)^2. This formula also shows why we have no real solutions when b^2<4ac 'since we would need to take the square root of 'a negative number.

about.title: About
about.text:
Freemaths is designed to help students quickly develop their mathematics, whilst enabling parents and teachers to efficiently support this process.

An overview of how (and why) Freemaths works is given in this guide.

The easiest way to see what Freemaths does is to try it for yourself. Please contact us if you would like to know more or get involved. It is early days for the site but we look forward to helping every student perform well in mathematics.

As the name suggests use of the Freemaths site is completely free. The site carries no advertising and cookies are not used for any purpose other than identifying who you are for the site's functionality. The site is covered by UK data legislation with registration number Z8216806.

classes_faq.title: Classes FAQ
classes_faq.text:
Who are the classes suitable for?

The classes are ideal for students in year '10 or year '11 expecting to take GCSEs in '2018 or '2019.

What makes these Master classes?

The classes cover the most difficult GCSE topics. These topics are often covered very late by schools and not in great detail (or not at all for lower sets) but they are essential to gain the highest grades. Much of the joy in mathematics comes from the deeper understanding more advanced topics give.

Do students need to be high-performing to attend Master classes?

No, all that is required is a desire to do well and a willingness to invest the effort to do so. The classes aim to help all students to become high-performing.

Who will deliver the classes?

All classes will be delivered in person by Ed Darnell the creator of www.freemaths.uk

Ed is a highly qualified mathematics teacher with many years commercial computing and leadership experience. Ed holds a BSc. in Mathematics and Computing from Sheffield University and a PGCE and Masters in Mathematics Education from the Institute of Education.

What if I can’t make all classes?

The intention is to re-run the classes regularly so there is no need to attend them all at once. Why not try the first class and see how you get on?

Can I use www.freemaths.uk without attending classes?

Most definitely. The very best way to develop mathematics is by doing. The site has been specifically designed to help this, providing all the feedback students require to learn. It is completely free to use.

typing_maths.title: Typing Maths
typing_maths.text: FreeMaths attempts to format and display any maths you type. Try adding brackets around your maths if it fails to detect it. To prevent a word being recognised as maths precede it with a '' Use keyboard shortcuts or the provided buttons to enter maths symbols. Hover over the buttons to find the keyboard shortcut. If you enclose an expression in curly brackets FreeMaths attempts to calculate the value for you. E.g. '{11*5+4*2/3,mixed} gives {11*5+4*2/3,mixed} Katex is used for formatting mathematics. If FreeMaths is unable to format your expression you can try entering Katex directly. You may see Katex error messages to help correct any issues. Limits for integrals, sums etc. can be entered using _ for the lower limit and ^ for the upper limit. Multiple characters must be enclosed in curly brackets { }. E.g. '∫_1^{10} gives ∫_1^{10} Please contact us if you have any issues or requests. We aim to make communicating mathematics as easy as possible.
